analyzed: saṃsāra paṅka uttīrna tvāt saṃsāra paṅka uttaraṇa mārga avasthita tvāt ca saṅghe pi prasāda ātmikā eva
translated: Faith, characterized by clarity, is also in the Saṅgha because it causes the crossing over of the mire of saṃsāra and because it is the path for crossing over the mire of saṃsāra.

original: śraddhā hi trividhā pravartate /🔽sati vastuni guṇavaty aguṇavati vā sampratyayākārā /🔽sati guṇavati ca prasādākārā /
analyzed: śraddhā hi trividhā pravartate  sati vastuni guṇavati aguṇavati vā sampratyaya ākārā  sati guṇavati ca prasāda ākārā
translated: For faith operates in three ways.🔽When there is a real object, whether it has good qualities or not, it operates with the mode of conviction.🔽When there is a real object with good qualities, it operates with the mode of clarity.

original: sati guṇavati ca prāptum utpādayituṃ śakye 'bhilāṣākārā /
analyzed: sati guṇavati ca prāptum utpādayitum śakye bhilāṣa ākārā
translated: When there is a real object with good qualities that can be attained or produced, it operates with the mode of desire.

analyzed: nanu evam abhilāṣa ākāra tvāt tṛṣṇā chandayoḥ anyatarā bhavati
translated: Isn't it that in this way, because it has the mode of desire, it is either craving or will?

analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: kuśala viṣaya tvāt na tṛṣṇā
translated: It is not craving because it has wholesome objects.

analyzed: śraddhā pūrvaka tvāt chandasya na chandaḥ
translated: It is not will because will is preceded by faith.

analyzed: cetasaḥ prasādaḥ iti
translated: It is the clarity of mind.

original: śraddhā hi cittakāluṣyavairodhikīty atas tatsamprayoge kleśopakleśamalakāluṣyavigamāc cittaṃ śraddhām āgamya prasīdatīti cetasaḥ prasāda ucyate
analyzed: śraddhā hi citta kāluṣya vairodhikī iti atas tad samprayoge kleśa upakleśa mala kāluṣya vigamāt cittam śraddhām āgamya prasīdati iti cetasaḥ prasādaḥ ucyate
translated: For faith is incompatible with the impurity of the mind. Therefore, when it is associated with it, due to the removal of the impurity of the defilements and secondary defilements, the mind becomes clear, relying on faith. Thus, it is called mental clarity.

analyzed: udaka prasādaka maṇi sthānīyam dharma antaram caitasikam śraddhā
translated: Faith is a separate mental factor that is like a water-purifying gem.

original: na rūpaprasādātmiketi pradarśanārtham āha cetasaḥ prasāda iti /
analyzed: na rūpa prasāda ātmikā iti pradarśana artham āha cetasaḥ prasādaḥ iti
translated: To show that it is not of the nature of the clarity of form, it is said: mental clarity.

analyzed: cetasaḥ prasādaḥ
translated: It is the clarity of the mind.

analyzed: na rūpasya iti
translated: Not of form.

analyzed: sā punar chanda sanniśraya dāna karmikā
translated: And its function is to support desire.

analyzed: hrīḥ katamā
translated: What is shame?

analyzed: ātmānam dharmam vā adhipatim kṛtvā avadyena lajjā
translated: It is a sense of shame with regard to evil deeds, taking oneself or the Dharma as the standard.

original: yatpratibaddhā yasya kriyāsu pravṛttir nivṛttir vā sa tasyādhipatiḥ svāp / mītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yad pratibaddhā yasya kriyāsu pravṛttiḥ nivṛttiḥ vā sa tasya adhipatiḥ svāp
translated: That to which something is related, by which there is engagement or disengagement in actions, is the dominant condition of that, meaning it is like a master.

analyzed: ātmānam dharmam vā adhipatim svāminam kṛtvā
translated: Taking oneself or the Dharma as the dominant, as the master.

original: sadbhir vigarhitatvād aniṣṭavipākatvāc ca pāpam evāvadyam /
analyzed: sadbhiḥ vigarhita tvāt aniṣṭa vipāka tvāt ca pāpam eva avadyam
translated: Evil is that which is censured by the virtuous and has undesirable results.

analyzed: tena avadyena kṛtena akṛtena vā cittasya avalīna tā lajjā
translated: With regard to that evil, whether done or not done, the timidity of the mind is shame.

original: kulajñānādibhir guṇaiḥ pāpakriyāyām ātmānam ayogyaṃ matvā /
analyzed: kula jñāna ādibhiḥ guṇaiḥ pāpa kriyāyām ātmānam ayogyam matvā
translated: Considering oneself unfit for evil deeds due to such qualities as family, knowledge, etc.

original: kathaṃ hi nāma mayaivaṃvidhenaivaṃ pāpaṃ kṛtaṃ kriyate kariṣyate vā /
analyzed: katham hi nāma mayā evaṃvidhena evam pāpam kṛtam kriyate kariṣyate vā
translated: How could I, who am like this, have done, am doing, or would do such an evil deed?

original: dharme 'py etad aniṣṭavipākatvāt paropaghātapravṛttatvāc ca garhitam ity evaṃ yātmānaṃ dharmaṃ cāvekṣamāṇasyāvadyena lajjā /
analyzed: dharme pi etat aniṣṭa vipāka tvāt para upaghāta pravṛtta tvāt ca garhitam iti evam yā ātmānam dharmam ca avekṣamāṇasya avadyena lajjā
translated: Even in regard to Dharma, it is reprehensible because it has such undesirable results and because it is engaged in harming others. Thus, when one regards oneself and Dharma in this way, there is shame at evil.

analyzed: sā hrīḥ
translated: That is modesty.

analyzed: iyam ca duścarita saṃyamana sanniśraya dāna karmikā
translated: And this has the function of providing a basis for restraining from misconduct.

analyzed: apatrāpyam katamat
translated: What is lack of shame?

analyzed: lokam adhipatim kṛtvā avadyena lajjā
translated: It is shame at evil deeds with regard to the world.

analyzed: loke hi etat garhitam
translated: For this is reproached in the world.

original: māṃ caivaṅkarmāṇaṃ viditvā vigarhiṣyantīty aślokādibhayād avadyena lajjate /
analyzed: mām ca evaṅkarmāṇam viditvā vigarhiṣyanti iti aśloka ādi bhayāt avadyena lajjate
translated: And thinking They will know that I have done such deeds and will reproach me, one is ashamed of evil deeds out of fear of infamy and so on.

analyzed: idam api duścarita saṃyamana sanniśraya dāna karmakam eva
translated: This also has the function of providing a basis for restraining from misconduct.

analyzed: duścaritāt viratiḥ saṃyamanam
translated: Restraint is abstaining from misconduct.

original: lajjamānasyāpatrapamāṇasya vā kṛte 'pi duścarite 'vaśyaṃ tadviramaṇād anayos tap / tsanniśrayadānakarmakatvam //
analyzed: lajjamānasya apatrapamāṇasya vā kṛte pi duścarite vaśyam tad viramaṇāt anayoḥ tap  /
translated: Because one who is ashamed or embarrassed necessarily abstains from misconduct even when it has been done, these two have the function of providing a basis for that.

analyzed: alobhaḥ iti
translated: Non-greed.

analyzed: ayam akāraḥ triṣu artheṣu vartate
translated: This negative particle occurs in three meanings:

analyzed: abhāve
translated: In the absence of something,

analyzed: ni asmin pratipakṣe ca
translated: and in another, and in the antidote.

original: atra pratipakṣa eva vartate nānyasmin nābhāva iti pradarśanārtham āha lobhapratipakṣa iti /
analyzed: atra pratipakṣe eva vartate na anyasmin na abhāvaḥ iti pradarśana artham āha lobha pratipakṣe iti
translated: In order to show that the antidote functions here, not elsewhere, not in non-existence, he says the antidote to greed.

analyzed: evam a dveṣe a mohe ca vaktavyam
translated: Similarly, it should be said for non-hatred and non-delusion.
Disenchantment and non-attachment defines its essential nature.

original: lobho nāma bhave bhavopakaraṇeṣu ca āsaktiḥ prārthanā ca /
analyzed: lobhaḥ nāma bhave bhava upakaraṇeṣu ca āsaktiḥ prārthanā ca
translated: Greed is attachment and desire towards existence and the requisites of existence.

original: tatpratipakṣo 'lobho bhave bhavopakaraṇeṣu cānāsaktir vaimukhyaṃ ca /
analyzed: tad pratipakṣaḥ lobhaḥ bhave bhava upakaraṇeṣu ca anāsaktiḥ vaimukhyam ca
translated: The antidote to that is non-greed, which is non-attachment and aversion towards existence and the requisites of existence.

original: nirvid bhavabhogādīnavānāṃ parijñānād bhave bhavopakaraṇeṣu ca vaimukhyam /
analyzed: nirvid bhava bhoga ādīnavānām parijñānāt bhave bhava upakaraṇeṣu ca vaimukhyam
translated: Disenchantment is aversion towards existence and the requisites of existence due to the thorough knowledge of the faults of worldly enjoyment and existence.

analyzed: anāgrahaḥ bhava bhava bhogayoḥ asaktiḥ
translated: Non-attachment is non-attachment towards existence and the requisites of worldly enjoyment.

original: athavānāgrahaviśeṣaṇārthaṃ nirvidgrahaṇaṃ bhave bhavopakaraṇeṣu ca vaimukhyākāro yo 'nāgraho 'yam alobha iti /
analyzed: athavā an āgraha viśeṣaṇa artham nirvid grahaṇam bhave bhava upakaraṇeṣu ca vaimukhya ākāraḥ yaḥ na āgrahaḥ yam alobhaḥ iti
translated: Or, the mention of disenchantment is for the purpose of specifying non-attachment. Non-attachment, which has the aspect of aversion towards existence and the requisites of existence, is non-greed.

analyzed: ayam ca duścarita apravṛtti sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ iti
translated: And this has the function of providing support for not engaging in misconduct.

analyzed: a dveṣaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is non-hatred?

analyzed: dveṣa pratipakṣaḥ maitrī
translated: The antidote to hatred is friendliness.

original: dveṣo hi sattveṣu duḥkhe duḥkhasthānīyeṣu ca dharmeṣv āghātaḥ /
analyzed: dveṣaḥ hi sattveṣu duḥkhe duḥkha sthānīyeṣu ca dharmeṣu āghātaḥ
translated: For hatred is hostility towards beings and towards phenomena that are the basis of suffering.

analyzed: tad pratipakṣaḥ na āghātaḥ
translated: Its antidote is non-hostility.

original: dveṣasyānye 'pi pratipakṣāḥ santīty ata āha maitrī /
analyzed: dveṣasya anye pi pratipakṣāḥ santi iti atas āha maitrī
translated: Since there are other antidotes to hatred, he says loving-kindness.

analyzed: maitra ātmakaḥ dveṣasya yaḥ pratipakṣaḥ saḥ dveṣaḥ
translated: The non-hatred that is the antidote to hatred is that which has loving-kindness as its nature.

analyzed: na anyaḥ iti
translated: It is not something else.

analyzed: ayam api iti
translated: This also has the function of providing a basis for not engaging in misconduct.

analyzed: amohaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is non-delusion?

analyzed: moha pratipakṣaḥ bhūta sampratipattiḥ
translated: It is the correct understanding of reality, which is the antidote to delusion.

original: sarva eva hi kuśalā dharmāḥ kliṣṭānāṃ dharmāṇāṃ samudācāravirodhāt pratipakṣa ity ata āha bhūtasampratipattir iti /
analyzed: sarve eva hi kuśalāḥ dharmāḥ kliṣṭānām dharmāṇām samudācāra virodhāt pratipakṣaḥ iti atas āha bhūta sampratipattiḥ iti
translated: Since all wholesome dharmas are antidotes to defiled dharmas because they oppose their arising, he says correct understanding of reality.

analyzed: saṃyak a viparīta pratipatti bhedāt
translated: Because of the difference between correct and inverted understanding.

original: sā punar dvividhā jñānaṃ pratisaṅkhyā ca /
analyzed: sā punar dvividhā jñānam pratisaṅkhyā ca
translated: Moreover, it is twofold: knowledge and critical consideration.

analyzed: punar caturvidhā vipāka āgama cintā adhigama nimittā
translated: And again, it is fourfold: based on ripening, scripture, reflection, and realization.

original: pratisaṅkhyā tu prajñaiva dhairyasahitā /🔽dhairyam iti prajñāvīryasamādhaya ucyante /
analyzed: pratisaṅkhyā tu prajñā eva dhairya sahitā  dhairyam iti prajñā vīrya samādhayaḥ ucyante
translated: But critical consideration is wisdom accompanied by firmness.🔽Firmness is said to be wisdom, effort, and concentration.

original: tatra dvayoḥ prajñādravyayoḥ samavadhānāsambhavād vīryeṇa samādhinā vā samprayuktā prajñā pratisaṅkhyety ucyate /
analyzed: tatra dvayoḥ prajñā dravyayoḥ samavadhāna asambhavāt vīryeṇa samādhinā vā samprayuktā prajñā pratisaṅkhyā iti ucyate
translated: Since it is impossible for the two substances of wisdom to be combined, wisdom accompanied by effort or concentration is called critical consideration.

analyzed: kleśānām avakāśan na dadati
translated: By whose power, even though the seeds of the defilements have not been uprooted or destroyed, they do not give an opportunity for the defilements.

original: ayam atra vākyārthaḥ yathābhūtajñānātmakaḥ pratisaṅkhyātmakaś ca jñānaviśeṣo 'moha ity ucyate /
analyzed: ayam atra vākya arthaḥ yathā bhūta jñāna ātmakaḥ pratisaṅkhyā ātmakaḥ ca jñāna viśeṣaḥ mohaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Here is the meaning of the sentence: The knowledge that consists of the knowledge of reality and the knowledge that consists of the knowledge of the self are called non-delusion.

analyzed: atas eva amohaḥ duścarita apravṛtti sat niśraya dāna karmakaḥ
translated: For this very reason, non-delusion has the function of giving support for the non-occurrence of misconduct.

analyzed: vīryam katamat
translated: What is vigor?

analyzed: kausīdya pratipakṣaḥ kuśale cetasaḥ bhyutsāhaḥ  kutsitam sīdati iti kusīdaḥ
translated: It is the antidote to laziness and the mental enthusiasm for the wholesome.🔽Kusīda means that which sinks down in what is despised.

analyzed: tad bhāvaḥ kausīdyam
translated: That state is laziness.

analyzed: ālasyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is indolence.

analyzed: tat ca kuśala akuśalayoḥ cittasya anutsāhaḥ
translated: And that is the lack of enthusiasm in the mind for the wholesome and the unwholesome.

original: tatpratipakṣaś ca vīryam ity ataḥ kausīdyavad ubhayaprasaṅge vyavacchedārtham p / āha kuśale cetaso 'bhyutsāho vīryam /
analyzed: tad pratipakṣaḥ ca vīryam iti atas kausīdya vat ubhaya prasaṅge vyavaccheda artham āha kuśale cetasaḥ bhyutsāhaḥ vīryam
translated: And its antidote is vigor. Therefore, in order to exclude both possibilities, like laziness, he says: Vigor is the mental enthusiasm for the wholesome.

analyzed: na tu kliṣṭaḥ iti
translated: But not for the defiled.

analyzed: kliṣṭe tu utsāhaḥ kutsita tvāt kausīdyam eva
translated: And the enthusiasm for the defiled, because it is despised, is just laziness.

original: nanu ca kliṣṭaṃ svabhyastatvāt svarasenaiva pravartate /
analyzed: nanu ca kliṣṭam su abhyasta tvāt sva rasena eva pravartate
translated: Isn't it that the defiled [mind] proceeds by its own nature due to being well-practiced?

analyzed: kim tatra utsāhena  prāyeṇa evam
translated: What is the need for enthusiasm there?🔽For the most part, it is so.

analyzed: asti tu kiñcid yatra utsāhaḥ api apekṣyate
translated: But there is something where enthusiasm is also required.

original: tat punar yatsamprayogāt sannāhe prayoge vālīnatve vāvyāvṛttau vāsantuṣṭau vā kuśaleṣu dharmeṣu cetaso 'bhyutsāhaḥ /
analyzed: tat punar yat samprayogāt sannāhe prayoge vā alīna tve vā a vyāvṛttau vā asantuṣṭau vā kuśaleṣu dharmeṣu cetasaḥ bhyutsāhaḥ
translated: Moreover, it is the mental enthusiasm in wholesome dharmas due to association with that, in armoring, in practice, in non-laxity, in non-retrogression, or in satisfaction.

analyzed: tat vīryam
translated: That is vigor.

analyzed: kuśala pakṣa paripūraṇa pariniṣpādana karmakam  paripūraṇam yathā maula praveśaḥ
translated: Its action is to fulfill and perfect the wholesome side.🔽Fulfilling is like entering the main [practice].

analyzed: pariniṣpādanam tasya eva parikarma kṛta tvam
translated: Perfecting is the very same [practice] being well-refined.

analyzed: prasrabdhiḥ katamā
translated: What is serenity?

analyzed: dauṣṭhulya pratipakṣaḥ kāya citta karmaṇya tā
translated: It is the serviceability of body and mind, the antidote to unserviceability.

analyzed: dauṣṭhulyam kāya cittayoḥ akarmaṇya tā sāṅkleṣika dharma bījāni ca
translated: Unserviceability is the unserviceability of body and mind and the seeds of defiled dharmas.

analyzed: tad apagame prasrabdhi sadbhāvāt dauṣṭhulya pratipakṣaḥ
translated: Since serenity exists when that [unserviceability] is absent, it is the antidote to unserviceability.

analyzed: lakṣaṇam tu prasrabdheḥ kāya citta karmaṇya tā
translated: But the characteristic of serenity is the serviceability of body and mind.

original: tatra kāyakarmaṇyatā kāyasya svakāryeṣu laghusamutthānatā yato bhavati /
analyzed: tatra kāya karmaṇya tā kāyasya sva kāryeṣu laghu samutthāna tā yatas bhavati
translated: Among them, the serviceability of body is the lightness and quickness of the body in its own activities, from which it arises.

original: cittakarmaṇyatā samyaṅmanasikāraprayuktasya hlādalāghavanimittaṃ yac caitasikaṃ dharmāntaram /
analyzed: citta karmaṇya tā samyak manasikāra prayuktasya hlāda lāghava nimittam yat caitasikam dharma antaram
translated: The serviceability of mind is a certain mental factor that is the cause of delight and lightness for one who is engaged in proper attention.

original: tadyogāc cittam asaktam ālambane pravartata ity atas tac cittakarmaṇyatety ucyate /
analyzed: tad yogāt cittam asaktam ālambane pravartate iti atas tat citta karmaṇya tā iti ucyate
translated: And because of that, the mind functions without attachment to the object, therefore it is called the pliability of mind.

original: kāyap / sya punaḥ spraṣṭavyaviśeṣa eva prītyāhṛtaḥ kāyaprasrabdhir veditavyā /
analyzed: punar spraṣṭavya viśeṣaḥ eva prīti āhṛtaḥ kāya prasrabdhiḥ veditavyā
translated: Moreover, bodily pliability should be understood as a special tactile sensation that is drawn in by joy.

original: prītamanasaḥ kāyaḥ prasrabhyata iti sūtre vacanāt /🔽atra caitasikādhikārād acaitasiky api kāyaprasrabdhiḥ prasrabdhisambodhyaṅgatvenoktā /
analyzed: prīta manasaḥ kāyaḥ prasrabhyate iti sūtre vacanāt  atra caitasika adhikārāt acaitasikī api kāya prasrabdhiḥ prasrabdhi sambodhi aṅga tvena uktā
translated: Because it is said in the sutra: The body of one whose mind is joyful becomes pliable.🔽And here, because of the predominance of mental factors, bodily pliability, which is not a mental factor, is mentioned as the factor of awakening that is pliability.

original: kāyakarmaṇyatā vā cittakarmaṇyatām āvāhayatīty ato 'caitasiky api kāyakarmaṇyatātroktā /
analyzed: kāya karmaṇya tā vā citta karmaṇya tām āvāhayati iti caitasikī api kāya karmaṇya tā atra uktā
translated: Or bodily pliability, which is not a mental factor, is mentioned here because it induces the pliability of mind.

analyzed: iyam ca śeṣa kleśa ādi āvaraṇa niṣkarṣaṇa karmikā
translated: And this [pliability] has the function of removing all the obscurations such as afflictions through the transformation of the basis by the power of that [pliability].

analyzed: apramādaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is heedfulness?

original: pramādapratipakṣo 'lobho yāvad vīryam /🔽yān niśrityākuśalān dharmān prajahāti /
analyzed: pramāda pratipakṣaḥ lobhaḥ yāvat vīryam  yān niśritya akuśalān dharmān prajahāti
translated: Heedfulness is the antidote to heedlessness, which is from non-greed up to vigor.🔽Relying on which, one abandons unwholesome dharmas.

analyzed: tad pratipakṣān ca kuśalān dharmān bhāvayati iti
translated: And cultivates the antidotes to them, which are wholesome dharmas.

original: pramādo hi yena kleśebhyaś cittaṃ na rakṣati kuśalaṃ ca hāpayati /
analyzed: pramādaḥ hi yena kleśebhyaḥ cittam na rakṣati kuśalam ca hāpayati
translated: For heedlessness is that by which the mind does not guard against the afflictions and loses the wholesome.

original: apramādena punaḥ kleśān prajahāti pratipakṣāṃś ca dharmān bhāvayatīty ato 'pramādaḥ pramādapratipakṣa uktaḥ /
analyzed: apramādena punar kleśān prajahāti pratipakṣān ca dharmān bhāvayati iti atas pramādaḥ pramāda pratipakṣaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Moreover, one abandons the defilements and cultivates the antidotes to the defilements through heedfulness. Therefore, heedfulness is said to be the antidote to heedlessness.

original: alobho yāvad vīryam ity alobhādveṣāmohāḥ saha vīryeṇa gṛhyante /
analyzed: a lobhaḥ yāvat vīryam iti a lobha a dveṣa a mohāḥ saha vīryeṇa gṛhyante
translated: Non-greed up to vigor: non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion along with vigor are included.

original: yān alobhādīn vīryaparyantān niśrityāgamya prāpyākuśalān dharmān prajahātīty anena sarve alobhādayo 'pramāda ity uktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yān alobha ādīn vīrya paryantān niśritya āgamya prāpya akuśalān dharmān prajahāti iti anena sarve alobha ādayaḥ pramādaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: By relying on, depending on, and attaining those non-greed and so on up to vigor, one abandons unwholesome dharmas. By this, it is said that all non-greed and so on are heedfulness.

original: akuśalā dharmā āsravā āsravasthānīyāś ca viṣayā veditavyāḥ /
analyzed: akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ āsravāḥ āsrava sthānīyāḥ ca viṣayāḥ veditavyāḥ
translated: Unwholesome dharmas should be understood as the outflows, the objects that are the basis of the outflows, and the objects that are similar to the outflows.

analyzed: tatra āsravāṇām vinodana viṣkambhaṇa bīja samuddhāra ātmakam prahāṇam
translated: There, the abandonment of the outflows is of the nature of dispelling, obstructing, and uprooting the seeds.

analyzed: viṣayāṇām punar parivarjanena prahāṇam
translated: Moreover, the abandonment of the objects is by avoiding them.

analyzed: tad pratipakṣāḥ iti akuśala dharma pratipakṣāḥ
translated: Those are the antidotes: the antidotes to unwholesome dharmas.

original: te punaḥ kuśalasāsravā anāsravāś ca /🔽teṣām abhyāso bhāvanā /
analyzed: te punar kuśala sa āsravāḥ anāsravāḥ ca  teṣām abhyāsaḥ bhāvanā
translated: Moreover, they are wholesome with and without outflows.🔽The cultivation of those is the repeated practice.

analyzed: paunaḥpunyena sammukhīkaraṇam
translated: It is the repeated manifestation.

original: yasmād vīryasahītān alobhādīn niśrityākuśalān dharmān prajahāti tatpratipakṣāṃś ca dharmān bhāvayati /
analyzed: yasmāt vīrya sahītān alobha ādīn niśritya akuśalān dharmān prajahāti tad pratipakṣān ca dharmān bhāvayati
translated: Because, relying on non-greed, etc. accompanied by effort, one abandons unwholesome dharmas and cultivates the dharmas that are their antidotes.

original: tasmāt savīryeṣv alobhādiṣv apramādaḥ prajñapyate ity anena sādhiṣṭhānā sakāraṇā cāpramādasya prajñaptir uktā /
analyzed: tasmāt sa vīryeṣu alobha ādiṣu apramādaḥ prajñapyate iti anena sa adhiṣṭhānā sa kāraṇā ca apramādasya prajñaptiḥ uktā
translated: Therefore, heedfulness is established in non-greed, etc. accompanied by effort. Thus, by this, the establishment of heedfulness is stated along with its basis and cause.

analyzed: sa punar sarva laukika lokottara sampatti paripūraṇa karmakaḥ
translated: Moreover, it has the function of fulfilling all mundane and supramundane perfections.

analyzed: tatra laukika sampattiḥ bhava bhoga viśeṣa lābhaḥ
translated: There, mundane perfection is the attainment of special worldly enjoyments.
Supramundane is the realization of the enlightenment of the śrāvakas, etc.

analyzed: upekṣā katamā
translated: What is equanimity?

original: sa evālobho yāvad vīryam ityādi apramāda ivātrāpi vyākhyānam /
analyzed: saḥ eva alobhaḥ yāvat vīryam ityādi apramādaḥ iva atra api vyākhyānam
translated: As in the case of heedfulness, the explanation here is also that it is non-greed up to effort.

original: cittasamatādibhis tribhiḥ padair upekṣāyā ādimadhyāvasānāvasthā dyotitā /
analyzed: citta samatā ādibhiḥ tribhiḥ padaiḥ upekṣāyāḥ ādi madhya avasāna avasthā dyotitā
translated: By the three terms beginning with mental balance, the initial, middle, and final stages of equanimity are indicated.

analyzed: tatra laya auddhatyam cetasaḥ vaiṣamyam
translated: There, mental imbalance is laxity and excitedness.

analyzed: tasya abhāvāt ādau cittasya samatā
translated: Due to the absence of that, at the beginning, the mind is balanced.

original: tato 'nabhisaṃskāreṇāprayatnena samāhitasya cetaso yathāyogaṃ samasyaiva pravṛttiḥ praśaṭhatā /
analyzed: tatas na abhisaṃskāreṇa aprayatnena samāhitasya cetasaḥ yathāyogam samasyā eva pravṛttiḥ praśaṭha tā
translated: Then, for one who is concentrated without effort, without exertion, the engagement of the mind itself in accordance with what is appropriate is calmness.

analyzed: sā punar avasthā laya auddhatya āśaṅkā anugatā
translated: Moreover, that state is accompanied by the suspicion of laxity and excitedness.

analyzed: acira bhāvita tvāt
translated: Because it is not yet well cultivated.

original: tato bhāvanāprakarṣagamanāt tadvipakṣadūrībhāvāt tacchaṅkābhāve layauddhatyapratipakṣanip / mitteṣv ābhogam akurvato 'nābhogāvasthatā cittasyānābhogatā
analyzed: tatas bhāvanā prakarṣa gamanāt tad vipakṣa dūrībhāvāt tad śaṅkā abhāve ābhogam a kurvataḥ na ābhoga avastha tā cittasya anābhoga tā
translated: Then, due to the attainment of excellence in cultivation, due to the remoteness of its opposing factors, in the absence of that suspicion, the mind becomes effortless in the state of not making effort in the antidotes to laxity and excitedness. Effortlessness

analyzed: yayā nirvāsiteṣu kliṣṭeṣu dharmeṣu iti
translated: by which defiled dharmas are expelled.

analyzed: yayā iti upekṣā eva sambadhyate
translated: By which is connected only to equanimity.

analyzed: kliṣṭāḥ dharmāḥ rāga ādi sahitāḥ
translated: Defiled dharmas are those accompanied by greed, etc.

analyzed: teṣām nirvāsanam punar anutpattiḥ
translated: Their expulsion is their non-arising again.

original: upekṣā hi saṅkliṣṭavihāravairodhikīty avaśyaṃ tayā rāgādipravṛttivibandhe vartitavyam ity atas tayā nirvāsiteṣv ity uktam /🔽yataś ca saṅkliṣṭena vihāreṇopekṣā virūdhyate /
analyzed: upekṣā hi saṅkliṣṭa vihāra vairodhikī iti avaśyam tayā rāga ādi pravṛtti vibandhe vartitavyam iti atas tayā nirvāsiteṣu iti uktam  yatas ca saṅkliṣṭena vihāreṇa upekṣā virūdhyate
translated: For equanimity is opposed to defiled abiding, so it must necessarily function to obstruct the occurrence of greed, etc. Therefore it is said in those expelled by it.🔽And because equanimity is incompatible with defiled abiding,

analyzed: tena upekṣā vihārī asaṅkliṣṭa vihārī bhavati iti
translated: one who abides in equanimity becomes one who abides without defilement.

analyzed: atas ca upekṣā saṅkleśa anavakāśa sanniśraya dāna karmikā
translated: And for this reason, equanimity has the function of giving support for the non-occurrence of defilement.

analyzed: avihiṃsā katamā
translated: What is non-violence?

analyzed: vihiṃsā pratipakṣaḥ karuṇā iti
translated: It is compassion, the antidote to violence.

analyzed: vadha bandha ādibhiḥ a viheṭhanam a drohaṇam sattvānām a vihiṃsā iti vihiṃsā pratipakṣaḥ
translated: Non-harming is the opposite of harming. It is not harming sentient beings by killing, binding, and so on.

analyzed: kam ruṇaddhi iti karuṇā
translated: Compassion is that which holds (ruṇaddhi) the kam (sukha).

analyzed: kam iti sukhasya ākhyā
translated: Kam is a designation for happiness.

analyzed: sukham ruṇaddhi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: it holds happiness.

analyzed: kāruṇikaḥ hi para duḥkha duḥkhī bhavati iti
translated: For one who is compassionate suffers from the suffering of others.

analyzed: iyam ca apramādavat prajñaptitaḥ eva
translated: And this [compassion], like heedfulness, exists only as a designation.

analyzed: na dravya satī
translated: It does not exist as a substance.

analyzed: a dveṣa aṃśaḥ eva prajñapanāt
translated: Because it is designated as just the part of non-hatred.

analyzed: a viheṭhana karmikā
translated: Its function is to prevent harming.

analyzed: uktāḥ ekādaśa kuśalāḥ
translated: The eleven wholesome [mental factors] have been explained.

analyzed: ṣaṭ kleśāḥ vaktavyāḥ
translated: The six defilements should be explained.

analyzed: te ucyante rāgaḥ katamaḥ
translated: They are said to be: What is desire?

analyzed: pañcasu upādāna skandheṣu snehaḥ dhī avasānam
translated: It is affection and attachment to the five aggregates subject to clinging.

analyzed: sa āsravāṇi rūpa vedanā sañjñā saṃskāra vijñānāni pañca rūpa vedanā sañjñā saṃskāra vijñāna upadāna skandhāḥ
translated: The five aggregates subject to clinging are the defiled form, feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness.

analyzed: tatra rūpa upādāna skandhaḥ dvaidhātukam rūpam
translated: Among them, the form aggregate subject to clinging is the form belonging to the two realms.

analyzed: vedanā ādi upādāna skandhāḥ catvāraḥ traidhātukāḥ vedanā ādayaḥ
translated: The four aggregates subject to clinging beginning with feeling are the feelings, etc. belonging to the three realms.

original: upādīyate 'nayā tṛṣṇayā tribhavotpattiḥ paunarbhavikaṃ vā karmeti tṛṣṇāyā upādānākhyā /
analyzed: upādīyate nayā tṛṣṇayā tri bhava utpattiḥ paunarbhavikam vā karma iti tṛṣṇāyāḥ upādāna ākhyā
translated: Because rebirth in the three existences or the karma leading to rebirth is appropriated by this craving, craving is called clinging.

original: upādānasambhūtatvād upādānavidheyatvād upādānāni vā tebhyaḥ sambhavantīty upādānaskandhāḥ /
analyzed: upādāna sambhūta tvāt upādāna vidheya tvāt upādānāni vā tebhyaḥ sambhavanti iti upādāna skandhāḥ
translated: They are called aggregates of clinging because they originate from clinging, because they are subject to clinging, or because the clingings originate from them.

analyzed: snehaḥ iva snehaḥ
translated: Affection is like oil.

original: yathā hi tailādikaḥ sneho vastrādikam āśrayam anupraviśya vyāpnoti /
analyzed: yathā hi taila ādikaḥ snehaḥ vastra ādikam āśrayam anupraviśya vyāpnoti
translated: Just as oil, etc., as an affection, penetrates and pervades a cloth, etc., as a basis,

analyzed: mahatā api ca yatnena sva āśrayāt durvivecyaḥ
translated: and is difficult to separate from its basis even with great effort,

original: evaṃ rāgo 'pi svālambanam anupraviśyaiva vyāpnoti mahatāpi ca prayāsena tasmādālambanāt durvivecya iti sneha ucyate /
analyzed: evam rāgaḥ sva ālambanam anupraviśya eva vyāpnoti mahatā api ca prayāsena tasmāt ālambanāt durvivecyaḥ iti snehaḥ ucyate
translated: so too attachment, having penetrated its object, pervades it, and is difficult to separate from that object even with great effort. Therefore it is called affection.

analyzed: adhyavasānam tad maya tā
translated: Adherence is the state of being full of that.

original: athavā spraṣṭavyaviśeṣo 'pi sneha iti vyavacchedārtham āha adhyavasānam iti /
analyzed: athavā spraṣṭavya viśeṣaḥ snehaḥ iti vyavaccheda artham āha adhyavasānam iti
translated: Or, a special tangible object is also called affection. To distinguish it, he says adherence.

analyzed: sa punar duḥkha sañjanana karmakaḥ
translated: And its function is to generate suffering.

original: triduḥkhatāyogād yathāsambhavaṃ traidhātukāḥ pañca skandhā duḥkham abhipretam tasya ca duḥkhasya kāmarūpārūpyatṛṣṇāvaśenābhinirvṛttito rāgasya
analyzed: tri duḥkha tā yogāt yathāsambhavam traidhātukāḥ pañca skandhāḥ duḥkham abhipretam tasya ca duḥkhasya kāma rūpa ārūpya tṛṣṇā vaśena abhinirvṛttitaḥ rāgasya
translated: The five aggregates in the three realms are intended as suffering, in accordance with the three types of suffering. And because that suffering arises under the influence of craving for desire, form, and formlessness, the function of attachment

analyzed: duḥkha sañjananam karma nirdiśyate
translated: is indicated as generating suffering.

analyzed: pratighaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is resistance?

analyzed: sattveṣu āghātaḥ iti
translated: It is hostility towards beings.

original: āghātaḥ sattveṣu rūkṣacittatā yenāviṣṭaḥ sattvānāṃ vadhabandhādikam anarthaṃ cintayati /
analyzed: āghātaḥ sattveṣu rūkṣa citta tā yena āviṣṭaḥ sattvānām vadha bandha ādikam anartham cintayati
translated: Hostility is a harshness of mind towards sentient beings, by which one, being possessed, thinks of harming sentient beings such as killing, binding, and so on.

analyzed: sa punar a sparśa vihāra duścarita sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ
translated: It has the function of giving support to unpleasant dwelling and misconduct.

analyzed: sparśaḥ sukham
translated: Touch is happiness.

analyzed: tena sahitaḥ vihāraḥ sparśavihāraḥ
translated: Dwelling together with that is pleasant dwelling.

analyzed: na sparśavihāraḥ sparśavihāraḥ
translated: Not pleasant dwelling is unpleasant dwelling.

analyzed: duḥkha sahitaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: accompanied by suffering.

analyzed: āghāta cittasya avaśyam daurmanasya samudācārāt cittam tapyate
translated: Because of the necessarily manifest discontent of a hostile mind, the mind is tormented.

analyzed: citta anuvidhānāt ca kāyaḥ tapyate eva iti
translated: And because the body conforms to the mind, the body is also tormented.

analyzed: sarva īryāpatheṣu sa duḥkha sa vighātaḥ sya vihāraḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, his dwelling is always accompanied by suffering and obstruction in all his activities.

original: pratihatacittasya ca na kiñcid duścaritaṃ vidūr iti pratigho 'sparśavihāraduścaritasanniśrayadānakarmaka uktaḥ //
analyzed: pratihata cittasya ca na kiñcid duścaritam viduḥ iti pratighaḥ sparśa vihāra duścarita sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ uktaḥ
translated: And because there is no misconduct for one with a hostile mind, hostility is said to have the function of giving support to unpleasant dwelling and misconduct.

analyzed: mānaḥ katamaḥ
translated: What is pride?

analyzed: sapta mānāḥ iti
translated: There are seven kinds of pride.

original: māno hi sarva eva satkāyadṛṣṭisanniśrayeṇa pravartate /
analyzed: mānaḥ hi sarvaḥ eva sat kāya dṛṣṭi sanniśrayeṇa pravartate
translated: For pride arises in dependence on the view of the transitory collection.

analyzed: cittasya ca unnati lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: And it has the characteristic of the mind's elevation.

original: tathā hy ātmātmīyabhāvaṃ skandheṣv adhyāropyāyam aham idaṃ mamety ātmānaṃ tena tena viśeṣeṇonnamayati anyebhyo 'dhikaṃ manyate /
analyzed: tathā hi ātma ātmīya bhāvam skandheṣu adhyāropya ayam aham idam mama iti ātmānam tena tena viśeṣeṇa unnamayati anyebhyaḥ dhikam manyate
translated: For, superimposing the notion of self and what belongs to self on the aggregates, one exalts the self with this or that distinction, thinking, I am this, this is mine, and considers it superior to others.

analyzed: sa ca agaurava duḥkha utpatti sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ
translated: And it functions as the basis for the production of disrespect and suffering.

original: agauravaṃ guruṣu guṇavatsu ca pudgaleṣu stabdhatā kāyavācor apasṛtatā /
analyzed: agauravam guruṣu guṇavatsu ca pudgaleṣu stabdha tā kāya vācoḥ apasṛta tā
translated: Disrespect is the stiffness of body and speech towards superiors and virtuous persons.

analyzed: duḥkha utpattiḥ punar atra punarbhava utpattiḥ veditavyā
translated: And the production of suffering here should be understood as the production of rebirth.

original: sa punaś cittonnatisvabhāvābhede 'pi cittonnatinimittabhedāt saptadhā bhidyate māno 'timāna ity evamādi //🔽hīnāt kulavijñānavittādibhiḥ śreyān asmi kulavijñānavittādibhir iti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: sa punar citta unnati svabhāva abhede citta unnati nimitta bhedāt saptadhā bhidyate māno timānaḥ iti evamādi  hīnāt kula vijñāna vitta ādibhiḥ śreyān asmi kula vijñāna vitta ādibhiḥ iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: And although it is undifferentiated in essence as the exaltation of mind, it is divided into seven types due to the differentiation of the causes of the exaltation of mind, such as pride, excessive pride, etc.🔽Pride is the exaltation of mind that thinks, I am superior in family, knowledge, wealth, etc. to those who are inferior in family, knowledge, wealth, etc.

original: sadṛśena vā kulādibhis tair eva sadṛśo 'smīti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: sadṛśena vā kula ādibhiḥ taiḥ eva sadṛśaḥ smi iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: Or, the exaltation of mind that thinks, I am equal to those who are equal to me in family, etc. and those very [qualities].

analyzed: sa mānaḥ
translated: That is pride.

original: atimānaḥ kulavijñānavittādibhiḥ sadṛśāt tyāgaśīlapauruṣādibhiḥ śreyān ap / smi /
analyzed: atimānaḥ kula vijñāna vitta ādibhiḥ sadṛśāt tyāga śīla pauruṣa ādibhiḥ śreyān ap
translated: Excessive pride is thinking, I am superior in generosity, morality, heroism, etc. to those who are equal to me in family, knowledge, wealth, etc.

original: śreyasā vā kulavittādibhiḥ sadṛśo 'smi vijñānavittādibhir iti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: śreyasā vā kula vitta ādibhiḥ sadṛśaḥ smi vijñāna vitta ādibhiḥ iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: When one thinks, I am equal to those who are superior in terms of family, wealth, etc., in terms of knowledge, wealth, etc., and one's mind becomes elevated,

analyzed: ayam atimānaḥ iti
translated: this is called excessive pride.

original: mānātimānaḥ śreyasaḥ kulavijñānavittair aham eva śreyān kulavijñānavittair iti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: māna atimānaḥ śreyasaḥ kula vijñāna vittaiḥ aham eva śreyān kula vijñāna vittaiḥ iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: Excessive pride is when one thinks, I am superior to those who are superior in terms of family, knowledge, and wealth, in terms of family, knowledge, and wealth, and one's mind becomes elevated.

analyzed: ayam māna atimānaḥ
translated: This is excessive pride.

analyzed: asmimānaḥ pañca upādāna skandhān iti
translated: The pride of I am is in relation to the five aggregates of clinging.

analyzed: chanda rāgau hi atra upādānam  anāgata ātma bhāva abhilāṣaḥ chandaḥ
translated: For here, clinging is desire and passion.🔽Desire is the longing for a future self.

analyzed: vartamāna adhyavasānam rāgaḥ
translated: Passion is the attachment to the present.

analyzed: tatra anāgata ātma bhāvam chanda mukhena upādatte
translated: There, one clings to the future self through the door of desire.

analyzed: vartamāna skandhān rāga mukhena a parityāgataḥ upādatte
translated: One clings to the present aggregates through the door of passion, not letting go.

original: ata etad eva dvayamupādānam ity ucyate /
analyzed: atas etat eva dvayam upādānam iti ucyate
translated: For this reason, these two alone are called clinging.

analyzed: tena yuktāḥ skandhāḥ upādāna skandhāḥ
translated: The aggregates associated with that are the aggregates of clinging.

analyzed: teṣu upādāna skandheṣu ātma ātmīya rahiteṣu ātma ātmīya abhiniveśāt yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: In those aggregates of clinging, which are devoid of self and what belongs to self, due to the false belief in self and what belongs to self, the elevation of mind

analyzed: ayam asmimānaḥ
translated: is the pride of I am.

original: abhimāno 'prāpta uttariviśeṣādhigame prāpto mayeti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: prāptaḥ uttari viśeṣa adhigame prāptaḥ mayā iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: Pride is when one thinks, I have attained the realization of a higher distinction that has not yet been attained, and one's mind becomes elevated.

analyzed: manuṣya dharmāḥ rāga dveṣa moha ādayaḥ
translated: Human qualities are passion, hatred, delusion, etc.

analyzed: tad pravartitam ca kāya vāc manaḥ karma
translated: And the bodily, verbal, and mental actions instigated by them.

analyzed: tad pratipakṣa bhūtam yat dhyāna samāpatti ādikam
translated: And the antidote to them is the attainment of meditation, etc.

analyzed: tat manuṣya dharmebhyaḥ uttari viśeṣaḥ ucyate
translated: That is said to be a superior distinction from human qualities.

original: tasmin viśeṣādhigama 'prāpte sati prāpto mayā uttariviśeṣādhigama iti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /🔽so 'bhimāp / naḥ /
analyzed: tasmin viśeṣa adhigama prāpte sati prāptaḥ mayā uttari viśeṣa adhigamaḥ iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ  saḥ bhimāp  /
translated: When that distinction is attained, the mental inflation thinking I have attained a superior distinction is pride.

original: ūnamāno bahvantaraviśiṣṭāt kulavidyāvittādibhir alpāntarahīno 'smi kulādibhir iti yā cittasyonnatiḥ /
analyzed: ūna mānaḥ bahu antara viśiṣṭāt kula vidyā vitta ādibhiḥ alpa antara hīnaḥ smi kula ādibhiḥ iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: Inferior pride is the mental inflation of one who, being slightly inferior to one greatly superior in family, learning, wealth, etc., thinks I am slightly inferior in family, etc.

analyzed: yuktam tāvat samena samaḥ
translated: It is reasonable that one who is equal thinks I am equal to him

analyzed: samānāt vā viśiṣṭaḥ
translated: or I am superior to one who is equal,

original: viśiṣṭād vā viśiṣṭa ity unnatisthānatvān mānaḥ /
analyzed: viśiṣṭāt vā viśiṣṭaḥ iti unnati sthāna tvāt mānaḥ
translated: or I am superior to one who is superior, because it is a basis for inflation.

original: ātmānaṃ tu nyūnaṃ paśyataḥ kim unnatisthānaṃ /
analyzed: ātmānam tu nyūnam paśyataḥ kim unnati sthānam
translated: But when one sees oneself as inferior, how can it be a basis for inflation?

analyzed: yatas tasya mānaḥ ucyate
translated: For how can that be called pride?

original: etad evonnatisthānaṃ bahvantaraviśiṣṭād alpāntarahīno 'smi na yathābahvantarahīnād iti /
analyzed: etat eva unnati sthānam bahu antara viśiṣṭāt alpa antara hīnaḥ smi na yathā bahu antara hīnāt iti
translated: This very thing is a basis for inflation: I am slightly inferior to one greatly superior, not as greatly inferior as to one slightly inferior.

original: api ca santi kecid ye prakṛṣṭe ca sattvarāśau hīnam apy ātmānaṃ bahu manyante /
analyzed: api ca santi kecid ye prakṛṣṭe ca sattva rāśau hīnam api ātmānam bahu manyante
translated: Moreover, there are some who think highly of themselves even in a group of superior beings.

analyzed: mithyā mānaḥ guṇavataḥ guṇavān asmi iti yā cittasya unnatiḥ
translated: False pride is the elevation of mind thinking I am endowed with virtues when one is not endowed with virtues.

analyzed: guṇāḥ dāna śīla kṣānti ādayaḥ
translated: Virtues are generosity, morality, patience, etc.

analyzed: te yasya na vidyante saḥ guṇavān
translated: One who does not have them is not endowed with virtues.

analyzed: athavā guṇāḥ dauḥśīlya ādayaḥ
translated: Or, non-virtues are immorality, etc.

analyzed: te yasya santi saḥ guṇavān
translated: One who has them is not endowed with virtues.

analyzed: tasmāt aguṇavataḥ guṇavān asmi iti
translated: Therefore, thinking I am endowed with virtues when one is not endowed with virtues,

original: aguṇavata iti anena hi dānaśīlādyabhāve guṇavattvam abhyupagataṃ bhavatīty ato nirvastukatvān mithyāmāna ucyate //
analyzed: aguṇavataḥ iti anena hi dāna śīla ādi abhāve guṇavat tvam abhyupagatam bhavati iti atas nirvastuka tvāt mithyāmānaḥ ucyate
translated: by this [statement] it is admitted that one is endowed with virtues even in the absence of generosity, morality, etc. Therefore, it is called false pride because it is groundless.

analyzed: avidyā katamā
translated: What is ignorance?

analyzed: karma phala satya ratneṣu ajñānam
translated: It is the lack of knowledge regarding actions, their results, the truths, and the jewels.

original: sā punaḥ p / sahajā parikalpitā ca /
analyzed: sā punar sahajā parikalpitā ca
translated: Moreover, it is innate and conceptual.

analyzed: tatra sahaja anya kleśa asamprayogāt āveṇikī
translated: Among them, the innate [ignorance] is independent because it is not associated with other afflictions.

analyzed: parikalpitā vicikitsā mithyādṛṣṭi śīla vrata parāmarṣa ādi kleśa samprayuktā
translated: The conceptual [ignorance] is associated with afflictions such as doubt, wrong view, and the extreme views of morality and asceticism, etc.

original: karmaṇy ajñānaṃ puṇyāpuṇyāniñjyakarmāstitve yad ajñānam apratipattir anavabodhaḥ /
analyzed: karmaṇi ajñānam yat ajñānam apratipattiḥ anavabodhaḥ
translated: The lack of knowledge regarding actions is the lack of knowledge, non-understanding, and non-realization regarding the existence of meritorious, non-meritorious, and immovable actions.

analyzed: iyam sahajā avidyā
translated: This is innate ignorance.

original: puṇyāpuṇyāniñjyakarmāstitve vicikitsato vāpavadato vā nāsti puṇyam apuṇyam āniñjyaṃ ceti /
analyzed: puṇya apuṇya aniñjya karma astitve vicikitsataḥ vā apavadataḥ vā na asti puṇyam apuṇyam āniñjyam ca iti
translated: Or for one who doubts or denies the existence of virtuous, non-virtuous, and imperturbable karma, thinking there is no virtue, non-virtue, or imperturbable [karma].

analyzed: paśubandha agnipraveśa ādi nivartane puṇye puṇya sañjñinām
translated: Or for those who regard animal sacrifice, entering fire, etc. as virtuous, but regard them as non-virtuous.

original: paśubandhāgnipraveśādike vāpuṇye puṇyasañjñināṃ yā vicikitsāmithyādṛṣṭisamprayuktā avidyā /
analyzed: paśubandha agnipraveśa ādike vā apuṇye puṇya sañjñinām yā vicikitsā mithyādṛṣṭi samprayuktā avidyā
translated: Or for those who regard animal sacrifice, entering fire, etc. as non-virtuous, but regard them as virtuous, the ignorance associated with doubt and wrong view.

analyzed: sā parikalpitā
translated: That is the imagined [ignorance].

analyzed: sā dharmeṣu mithyā niścaya vicikitsā saṅkleśa utpatti sanniśraya dāna karmikā
translated: Its function is to give rise to the defilements of wrong determination, doubt, and affliction regarding phenomena.

original: prajñā nitīraṇātmikā dṛṣṭir ucyata ity ato laukikīsaṃyagdṛṣṭyādiprasaṅge dṛṣṭir iti satkāyadṛṣṭyādikāḥ pañca dṛṣṭaya ihābhipretā iti pradarśann
analyzed: prajñā nitīraṇa ātmikā dṛṣṭiḥ ucyate iti atas laukikī saṃyak dṛṣṭi ādi prasaṅge dṛṣṭiḥ iti sat kāya dṛṣṭi ādikāḥ pañca dṛṣṭayaḥ iha abhipretāḥ iti pradarśan
translated: Since wisdom is said to have the nature of investigation and insight, in order to show that the five views such as the view of the transitory collection are intended here, in the context of the danger of [mistaking] worldly right view and so on,

analyzed: āha pañca dṛṣṭayaḥ iti
translated: he says the five views.

original: tāsāṃ kliṣṭatvāviśeṣe 'py āp / lambanākārabhedād bhedapradarśanārthaṃ punar apy āha satkāyadṛṣṭir antagrāhadṛṣṭir iti vistaraḥ //
analyzed: tāsām kliṣṭa tva aviśeṣe bheda pradarśana artham punar api āha sat kāya dṛṣṭiḥ anta grāha dṛṣṭiḥ iti vistaraḥ
translated: In order to show the difference between them, although they are all equally afflicted, he says again, the view of the transitory collection, the extreme views, and so on, in order to show the difference in their objects and aspects.

analyzed: nsīdati iti sat
translated: Sats means it sits (sīdati).

analyzed: cayaḥ kāyaḥ
translated: Kaya means accumulation (caya).

original: vinaśvare saṅghāte iyaṃ dṛṣṭir nātmani nātmīye ceti jñāpitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: vinaśvare saṅghāte iyam dṛṣṭiḥ na ātmani na ātmīye ca iti jñāpitam bhavati
translated: It is shown that this view is in regard to a perishable collection, not in regard to a self or what belongs to a self.

original: ātmā hi nityaś caikaś cātmavādibhir abhyupagamyate /
analyzed: ātmā hi nityaḥ ca ekaḥ ca ātma vādibhiḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: For the proponents of a self accept that the self is permanent and one.

original: iyaṃ cānityānekaviṣayatvān nātmaviṣayety uktaṃ bhavati /🔽pañcopādānaskandhān ityādi ye kecic chramaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ātmānam ātmīyaṃ veti samanupaśyantaḥ samanupaśyanti /
analyzed: iyam ca anitya aneka viṣaya tvāt na ātma viṣayā iti uktam bhavati  pañca upādāna skandhān ityādi ye kecid śramaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā ātmānam ātmīyam vā iti samanupaśyantaḥ samanupaśyanti
translated: And since this [view] has impermanent and multiple objects, it is said to not have a self as its object.🔽The sutra says, Whatever ascetics or brahmins are seen viewing the self or what belongs to the self, they view just these five aggregates.

original: ta imān eva pañcopādānaskandhān iti sūtra uktam /
analyzed: te imān eva pañca upādāna skandhān iti sūtre uktam
translated: The five aggregates are said to be the self or what belongs to the self.

original: te hi svarūpataḥ kāryato vā ātmānaṃ prajñapayeyuḥ /
analyzed: te hi svarūpataḥ kāryataḥ vā ātmānam prajñapayeyuḥ
translated: For they would designate the self in terms of its own nature or its effects.

analyzed: sāṅkhyāḥ caitanya svarūpam ātmānam manyante
translated: And the Samkhyas consider consciousness to be the nature of the self.

original: te ca cittacaitasikaprabhede 'vidvāṃsaḥ sakalaṃ cittacaitasikakalāpam eva caitanyam ity āhuḥ /
analyzed: te ca citta caitasika prabhede vidvāṃsaḥ sakalam citta caitasika kalāpam eva caitanyam iti āhuḥ
translated: And they, being ignorant of the distinction between mind and mental factors, say that consciousness is the entire collection of mind and mental factors.

original: atas te caturaḥ skandhān ātmeti pratipannāḥ /
analyzed: atas te caturaḥ skandhān ātmā iti pratipannāḥ
translated: Therefore, they regard the four mental aggregates as the self.

analyzed: rūpa skandham ātmīya tvena
translated: And the form aggregate as belonging to the self.

original: na ca buddhivṛttito 'nyac caitanyaṃ svasthacittena śakyate vaktuṃ pratipattum vā /
analyzed: na ca buddhi vṛttitaḥ nyat caitanyam svastha cittena śakyate vaktum pratipattum vā
translated: And it is not possible for one with a healthy mind to speak or understand consciousness as anything other than the activity of the intellect.

original: evam vedanādīnām ekeṣāṃ ca nirgranthānāṃ jñānasvarūpa ātmeti teṣām ātmātmīyagrāho 'nantarokta eva draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: evam vedanā ādīnām ekeṣām ca nirgranthānām jñāna svarūpaḥ ātmā iti teṣām ātmā ātmīya grāhaḥ nantara uktaḥ eva draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: In the same way, the view of the self and what belongs to the self should be understood as explained above in the case of those who consider feeling, etc., and some Nirgranthas to be the self that has the nature of knowledge.

original: vaiśeṣikādayas tu kāryata ātmānaṃ vyapadiśanti yaḥ paśyati yāvan manyate /
analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ tu kāryataḥ ātmānam vyapadiśanti yaḥ paśyati yāvat manyate
translated: However, the Vaiśeṣikas and others designate the self as the cause, saying, He who sees up to he who thinks,

original: tathā yo vedayate p / jānāti smarati cetayate vijānāti ca /🔽sa ātmeti /
analyzed: tathā yaḥ vedayate jānāti smarati cetayate vijānāti ca  saḥ ātmā iti
translated: and similarly, He who feels, knows, remembers, intends, and perceives is the self.

analyzed: teṣām api cakṣuḥ ādiṣu eva ātma abhimānaḥ
translated: But even for them, the self is conceived in relation to the eye and so on.

analyzed: yasmāt cakṣuḥ vyatiriktaḥ yaḥ paśyati tasya abhāvaḥ
translated: Because there is no one who sees apart from the eye.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vijñāne hi darśana samākhyā
translated: For the term seeing refers to visual consciousness.

analyzed: tasya a sādharaṇa kāraṇa tvāt cakṣuḥ paśyati iti vyapadiśyate
translated: And the eye is said to see because it is the unique cause of that [consciousness].

analyzed: tat yathā nādasya asādhāraṇa kāraṇa tvāt ghaṇṭā rauti iti ucyate
translated: Just as a bell is said to ring because it is the unique cause of the sound.

original: yatra tarhi cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā naiva sumanā bhavati naiva durmanā iti /
analyzed: yatra tarhi cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā na eva sumanāḥ bhavati na eva durmanāḥ iti
translated: But in the case where it is said, Having seen forms with the eye, one is neither pleased nor displeased,

analyzed: tatra katham
translated: how is that?

original: tatrāpi yatrātmaprajñaptiḥ samūhe santāne vā /🔽sa eva cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvety ucyate /
analyzed: tatra api yatra ātma prajñaptiḥ samūhe santāne vā  saḥ eva cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā iti ucyate
translated: Even there, where the designation of self is in relation to a collection or a continuum,🔽it is said that very [collection or continuum] sees forms with the eye.

analyzed: rūpa nirbhāsa tā eva hi rūpa darśanam
translated: For the mere appearance of form is the seeing of form.

analyzed: yasmāt tad bhāva abhāve rūpasya darśana adarśane vyavasthāpyete
translated: Because when that exists or does not exist, the appearance or non-appearance of form is determined.

analyzed: evam śravaṇa ādiṣu api vaktavyam
translated: The same should be said for hearing and so on.

analyzed: yatra tu uktam vedayate iti vedanā
translated: But where it is said feels, that is feeling.

analyzed: evam yāvat vijānāti iti vijñānam
translated: Similarly, up to cognizes, that is consciousness.

analyzed: tatra bhāva mātre kartṛ vyapadeśaḥ
translated: There, the designation of the agent is based on mere existence.

analyzed: vijñāna vyatirikta vijñātṛ pratiṣedha artham
translated: For the purpose of denying a cognizer separate from consciousness.

analyzed: evam vedanā ādiṣu api vaktavyam
translated: The same should be said for feeling and so on.

analyzed: athavā viṣaya nirbhāsa tām upādāya kartṛ vyapadeśaḥ
translated: Or else, the designation of the agent is based on the appearance of the object,

analyzed: yathā uktam prāk
translated: as stated earlier.

analyzed: na ca ātma lābha vyatiriktā kriyā vidyate
translated: And there is no action apart from the attainment of self-existence.

analyzed: kṣaṇika tvāt sarva bhāvānām kriyā kāle nava sthānāt
translated: Because all things are momentary, they do not remain at the time of action.

analyzed: na ca a kartṛkā kriyā asti
translated: And there is no action without an agent.

original: ātmalābhānantaraṃ ca bhāvānāṃ nirhetukatvād yadi vināśo na syāt /
analyzed: ātma lābha anantaram ca bhāvānām nirhetuka tvāt yadi vināśaḥ na syāt
translated: And if there were no destruction of things immediately after their attainment of self-existence, because they would be without cause,

analyzed: paścāt api na syāt
translated: it would not occur later either.

analyzed: vinaṣṭuḥ vināśasya ca paścāt ātma atiśaya abhāvāt
translated: Because the destroyed and the destruction have no further self-existence later.

original: sahetukavināśaparikalpe ca vinaṣṭaiva tadvyatirikto vā vināp / śahetuḥ parikalpyeta /
analyzed: sa hetuka vināśa parikalpe ca vinaṣṭā eva tad vyatiriktaḥ vā parikalpyeta
translated: And if destruction is imagined to have a cause, either the destroyed itself or something else apart from it would be imagined as the cause of destruction.

analyzed: pūrvasmin pakṣe ātma lābha anantaram bhāvānām vināśaḥ
translated: In the former case, things are destroyed immediately after they come into existence.

analyzed: na eva vā asti vināśaḥ iti prasajyate
translated: It follows that destruction does not exist at all.

analyzed: yaḥ pūrvam yasya na kāraṇam
translated: That which does not depend on anything else and was not previously a cause of something

original: sa paścād api tasya naiva kāraṇam /
analyzed: sa paścāt api tasya na eva kāraṇam
translated: is not a cause of that thing later on either.

analyzed: ātma atiśaya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no difference in its nature.

original: itarasminn api pakṣe vināśānāṃ kāraṇaniyamo na syāt /
analyzed: itarasmin api pakṣe vināśānām kāraṇa niyamaḥ na syāt
translated: In the other case as well, there would be no restriction on the causes of destruction.

original: kāryāṇām iva tadvināśānām api kāraṇaniyamo bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: kāryāṇām iva tad vināśānām api kāraṇa niyamaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Just as there is a restriction on the causes of effects, so too there would be a restriction on the causes of their destruction.

analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

original: kāryāṇāṃ hi parasparato bhinnasvarūpatvāt tatkāraṇānām api śaktibhedāt niyamo na virudhyate /
analyzed: kāryāṇām hi parasparataḥ bhinna sva rūpa tvāt tad kāraṇānām api śakti bhedāt niyamaḥ na virudhyate
translated: For effects, because their nature is different from each other, and because their causes also have different potencies, a restriction is not contradictory.

original: vināśānāṃ tu nirupākhyatvād ātmātiśayābhāve kiṅkṛto 'yaṃ niyamaḥ /
analyzed: vināśānām tu nirupākhya tvāt ātma atiśaya abhāve kiṅkṛtaḥ yam niyamaḥ
translated: But since destruction is non-existent, and there is no difference in its nature, how can there be this restriction?

analyzed: tasmāt sarvam vā vināśa kāraṇam sarva vināśasya
translated: Therefore, either everything is the cause of destruction of everything,

analyzed: na eva vā vināśa kāraṇam asti iti pratipattavyam
translated: or it should be understood that there is no cause of destruction at all.

original: vināśaś ca yadi vināśakāraṇāt pūrvam apy asti /
analyzed: vināśaḥ ca yadi vināśa kāraṇāt pūrvam api asti
translated: And if destruction exists even before the cause of destruction,

analyzed: evam sati vināśa kāraṇa vaiyarthyam prasajyeta
translated: then in that case the cause of destruction would be pointless.

original: bhāvānāṃ ca vināśe saty utpattir iti vinaṣṭānām apy utpattiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: bhāvānām ca vināśe sati utpattiḥ iti vinaṣṭānām api utpatti prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if things are produced when they are destroyed, then it follows that even destroyed things are produced.

analyzed: atha vināśa kāraṇebhyaḥ pūrvam na vidyate
translated: But if it does not exist prior to the causes of destruction,

original: evaṃ sati bhāvavad abhāvasyāpi prāgabhāvaḥ prajyate /
analyzed: evam sati bhāva vat abhāvasya api prāgabhāvaḥ prajyate
translated: then, in that case, like an existent thing, a non-existent thing is also seen to have prior non-existence.

analyzed: yasya ca prāgabhāvaḥ
translated: And for that which has prior non-existence,

analyzed: tasya ca avaśyam bhāva tvāt pradhvaṃsa abhāvena api bhavitavyam
translated: since it must necessarily be an existent thing, it must also exist as a subsequent non-existence.

original: evaṃ bhāvābhāvayor aviśeṣāt sarvaṃ bhāvātmakam abhāvātmakam vā prasajyeta /
analyzed: evam bhāva abhāvayoḥ aviśeṣāt sarvam bhāva ātmakam abhāva ātmakam vā prasajyeta
translated: Thus, because of the non-distinction between existent and non-existent things, it would follow that everything is either of the nature of an existent thing or of the nature of a non-existent thing.

analyzed: yadi ca pradhvaṃsa abhāvasya api pradhvaṃsa abhāvaḥ
translated: And if there is a subsequent non-existence even of the subsequent non-existence,

analyzed: evam pradhvaṃsa abhāvānām anavasthānāt tad kāraṇānām api
translated: in that case, because of the non-establishment of the subsequent non-existences, their causes would also [be non-existent].

analyzed: na iṣyate
translated: [This] is not accepted.

original: evaṃ sati bhāp / vapradhvaṃsābhāvasyāpi naiveṣṭavyā dvayor apy ātmātiśayatvābhāvāt /
analyzed: evam sati   na eva iṣṭavyā dvayoḥ api ātma atiśaya tva abhāvāt
translated: In that case, the subsequent non-existence of the subsequent non-existence should also not be accepted, because both [the subsequent non-existence and the subsequent non-existence of the subsequent non-existence] lack the nature of an existent thing.

analyzed: kriyā ca bhāvebhyaḥ nyā na anyā vā parikalpyeta
translated: And activity should be conceived as either different or non-different from existent things.

analyzed: yadi an anyā
translated: If [it is] non-different,

original: ātmaivātmanaḥ kartā karma ceti na yujyate /
analyzed: ātmā eva ātmanaḥ kartā karma ca iti na yujyate
translated: it is not tenable that the self itself is both the agent and the object of action.

analyzed: yadi ca labdha ātmakaḥ kriyām karoti
translated: And if that which has attained its own nature performs an action,

analyzed: na asau tasya ātma bhūtā
translated: it is not of the nature of that [action].

analyzed: yaḥ hi yena vinā api bhavati
translated: For that which exists even without something else,

analyzed: na sa tasya ātma bhūtaḥ yujyate
translated: it is not proper that it be the self of that.

analyzed: kriyā śūnye ca kartṛ tvam na yujyate
translated: And agency is not proper in what is devoid of action.

original: kriyārahitāc ca kriyādhyāsito 'nya eveti kathaṃ kartuḥ karmaṇo vātmabhūtā /
analyzed: kriyā rahitāt ca kriyā adhyāsitaḥ nyaḥ eva iti katham kartuḥ karmaṇaḥ vā ātma bhūtā
translated: And since it is different from what is devoid of action, being superimposed with action, how can it be the self of the agent or object?

analyzed: kriyā rahita tad adhyāsitayoḥ ca yaugapadya adarśanāt pūrva vināśaḥ uttarasya utpādaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: And since it is not seen that what is devoid of action and what is superimposed with action exist simultaneously, it must be accepted that the later one arises from the destruction of the earlier one.

analyzed: atha a labdha ātmakaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, it has not yet acquired a self,

original: evam api tasya kartṛtvaṃ kriyāyāś ca tadātmabhūtatvaṃ na yujyate /
analyzed: evam api tasya kartṛ tvam kriyāyāḥ ca tad ātma bhūta tvam na yujyate
translated: in that case also, its agency and the action's being its self are not proper.

analyzed: dvayoḥ api a sattvāt
translated: Because both are non-existent.

analyzed: kim ca ekasya kriyā rahita tvāt  dvitīyasya kriyā adhyāsita tvāt kartṛ tva abhāvaḥ
translated: Moreover, because one is devoid of action,🔽and the other is superimposed with action, there is no agency.

original: kartur abhāvāc ca kriyāyā apy abhāva iti /
analyzed: kartuḥ abhāvāt ca kriyāyāḥ api abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And because there is no agent, there is also no action.

original: evaṃ ca svarasavināśāt kṣaṇikatvam evābhyupagataṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam ca sva rasa vināśāt kṣaṇika tvam eva abhyupagatam bhavati
translated: And thus, because of destruction by its own nature, momentariness is indeed accepted.

original: kartṛkarmaṇor anyāpi kriyā naivāsti /🔽kārakair hi kriyā janyate /
analyzed: kartṛ karmaṇoḥ anyā api kriyā na eva asti  kārakaiḥ hi kriyā janyate
translated: And there is no action other than the agent and object.🔽For action is produced by the causes.

analyzed: janya tvāt ca karma eva bhavati
translated: And because it is produced, it becomes the object.

original: na ca niḥkriyaṃ karma kartā vā yujyata ity avaśyaṃ tatrānyayā kriyayā bhavitavyam /🔽tatrāpy anyayety anavasthā kriyāṇāṃ kartṝṇāṃ ca /
analyzed: na ca niḥkriyam karma kartā vā yujyate iti avaśyam tatra anyayā kriyayā bhavitavyam  tatra api anyayā iti anavasthā kriyāṇām kartṝṇām ca
translated: And an action or an agent without activity is not tenable. Therefore, there must necessarily be another activity there.🔽And in that case, there would be an infinite regress of activities and agents.

analyzed: atha kriyā akriyā antarām anapekṣā janyate
translated: But if an activity is produced without depending on another activity,

original: evaṃ tarhi dravyam eva p / kriyāntararahitaṃ janyatvena kiṃ neṣyate /
analyzed: evam tarhi dravyam eva kriyā antara rahitam janya tvena kim na iṣyate
translated: then why is it not accepted that just the substance, without another activity, is produced?

analyzed: kim artha antara bhūtayā adṛṣṭa sva rūpa sāmarthyayā kriyayā parikalpitayā
translated: What is the use of postulating an activity that has a nature and capacity that are not seen?

analyzed: yadi ca kriyā kārakaiḥ janyate
translated: And if an activity is produced by the causes,

analyzed: na dravyam
translated: not a substance,

analyzed: evam prāk pradhvaṃsa abhāvau kriyāyāḥ eva
translated: then prior non-existence and posterior non-existence belong only to the activity,

analyzed: na dravyasya iti sarva dravyāṇi nityāni
translated: not to the substance. Thus all substances are eternal.

analyzed: na eva vā santi iti abhyupeyam
translated: Or it must be accepted that they do not exist at all.

analyzed: yadi ca kārakebhyaḥ nyā kriyā
translated: And if an activity is different from the causes,

analyzed: kriyā rahitam ca sādhanam
translated: and the means of accomplishment is devoid of activity,

analyzed: evam kriyāṇām anavasthānam sādhana abhāvaḥ vā
translated: in the same way there would be an infinite regress of activities or the absence of means of accomplishment.

analyzed: sādhana abhāvāt ca
translated: And due to the absence of means of accomplishment, there would also be the absence of activity.

analyzed: na hi asādhanā kriyā asti
translated: For there is no activity without means of accomplishment.

analyzed: yadi ca gantuḥ anyā gatiḥ
translated: And if motion is different from the mover,

analyzed: taṇḍulebhyaḥ nyā paciḥ
translated: and cooking is different from the rice grains,

analyzed: evam sati gantuḥ na deśa antara prāptiḥ
translated: If this were so, there would be no reaching of another place for the goer.

analyzed: taṇḍulānām vā apacanam
translated: Or the cooking of the rice grains.

analyzed: pūrva avasthātaḥ vikṛta tvāt
translated: Because there is no change from the previous state.

original: atha kriyaiva svāśrayasya vikārahetur iti pūrvāvasthāto vikṛtatvam apratiṣiddham /
analyzed: atha kriyā eva sva āśrayasya vikāra hetuḥ iti pūrva avasthātaḥ vikṛta tvam a pratiṣiddham
translated: But if action itself is the cause of change for its substratum, then change from the previous state is not denied.

analyzed: vikāraḥ hi pūrvasmāt ātma atiśayaḥ
translated: For change is an excess of self over the previous state.

analyzed: sa ca anya tva avinābhāvī
translated: And that is inseparable from difference.

original: tasmād avaśyaṃ pūrvottarayor yaugapadyābhāvāt pūrvavināśenābhinnakālam uttarasyotpādo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt avaśyam pūrva uttarayoḥ yaugapadya abhāvāt pūrva vināśena abhinna kālam uttarasya utpādaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, because the previous and subsequent states cannot occur simultaneously, the arising of the subsequent state must be accepted as simultaneous with the destruction of the previous state.

original: evaṃ kriyāyā āśrayābhāvād anavasthitatvāt kuto vikārahetutvam /🔽tasmād ātmalābhānantaravināśeṣu nirīheṣv antarvyāpārapuruṣarahiteṣu pañcasūpādānaskandheṣv eva sadbhāvamātreṇa prāgabhūtānām anyeṣāṃ skandhānāṃ
analyzed: evam kriyāyāḥ āśraya abhāvāt anavasthita tvāt kutas vikāra hetu tvam  tasmāt ātma lābha anantara vināśeṣu nirīheṣu antar vyāpāra puruṣa rahiteṣu pañcasu upādāna skandheṣu eva sadbhāva mātreṇa prāgabhūtānām anyeṣām skandhānām
translated: Thus, how can action be the cause of change, since it has no substratum and is unstable?

original: hetubhāvena vyavasthiteṣu nityakartṛbhoktṛgrāhapūrvako 'yam ātmātmīyagrāhaḥ /🔽nātmany ātmīye ceti /
analyzed: hetu bhāvena vyavasthiteṣu nitya kartṛ bhoktṛ grāha pūrvakaḥ yam ātmā ātmīya grāhaḥ  na ātmani ātmīye ca iti
translated: Therefore, in the five aggregates that are to be appropriated, which are destroyed immediately after their attainment, are without effort, and are devoid of an inner operative person, the view of self and what belongs to the self arises based on the prior view of a permanent agent and experiencer, with those [aggregates] established as causes for other aggregates that did not exist before, merely by their existence.

original: p / ātmata ātmīyato cety antagrāhadṛṣṭito vyavacchinatti /
analyzed: ātmataḥ ca iti anta grāha dṛṣṭitaḥ vyavacchinatti
translated: [The Buddha] distinguishes [the view of self and what belongs to the self] from the view of grasping extremes, which is the view of self and what belongs to the self in relation to the self and what belongs to the self.🔽[The Buddha] distinguishes [the view of self and what belongs to the self] from the view of grasping extremes, which is the view of self and what belongs to the self in relation to the self and what belongs to the self.

analyzed: samanupaśyataḥ iti niścinvataḥ
translated: Contemplating means determining.

analyzed: yā kliṣṭā prajñā iti
translated: It is defiled wisdom.

original: na hy amūḍhasyānātmany ātmeti jñānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na hi amūḍhasya anātmani ātmā iti jñānam bhavati
translated: For one who is not deluded does not have the knowledge that what is non-self is a self.

analyzed: atas moha samprayogāt viparyasta tvāt ca kliṣṭā
translated: Therefore, it is defiled because it is associated with delusion and because it is inverted.

analyzed: tatra sva santati patitān ātmatvena samanupaśyati
translated: There, one contemplates as a self those [things] that fall within one's own continuum.

analyzed: para santati patitān an upāttān ca ātmīya tvena
translated: One contemplates as belonging to a self those [things] that fall within another's continuum and those that are not [included in any continuum].

analyzed: yadā api sva santati patitānām eka deśam ātmatvena
translated: Even when one contemplates as a self a part of those [things] that fall within one's own continuum,

original: tadā itarān apy ātmīyatvena /🔽iyaṃ ca sarvadṛṣṭigatasanniśrayadānakarmikā //
analyzed: tadā itarān api ātmīya tvena  iyam ca sarva dṛṣṭi gata sanniśraya dāna karmikā
translated: at that time one [also] contemplates the others as belonging to a self.🔽And this [view] has the function of providing a basis for all the views.

analyzed: tām eva adhipatim kṛtvā iti satkāyadṛṣṭim
translated: Taking that [view] as the dominant condition means taking the view of the transitory collection [as the dominant condition].

analyzed: sat kāya dṛṣṭi balena tad utpatteḥ
translated: Because it arises by the power of the view of the transitory collection,

analyzed: satkāyadṛṣṭiḥ tasyāḥ adhipatiḥ
translated: the view of the transitory collection is its dominant condition.

original: śāśvatata ucchedato veti yat satkāyadṛṣṭyātmatvena vastv ālambitam /
analyzed: śāśvatataḥ ucchedataḥ vā iti yat sat kāya dṛṣṭi ātma tvena vastu ālambitam
translated: As eternal or as subject to annihilation means that very thing which is taken as a self by the view of the transitory collection,

analyzed: tat eva śāśvatataḥ iti nityataḥ
translated: that very [thing] is contemplated as eternal, that is, as permanent.

analyzed: ucchedataḥ iti vināśaḥ
translated: As subject to annihilation means that here annihilation is destruction without rebirth.

original: samanupaśyato yā kliṣṭā prajñeti pūrvavad vācyam /
analyzed: samanupaśyataḥ yā kliṣṭā prajñā iti pūrvavat vācyam
translated: The defiled wisdom of one who contemplates should be explained as before.

analyzed: iyam ca madhyamā pratipad niryāṇa paripantha karmikā
translated: And this [wrong view] functions as an obstruction to the escape by means of the middle way.

analyzed: madhyamā pratipad śāśvata uccheda grāha varjitam pratītyasamutpāda jñānam
translated: The middle way is the knowledge of dependent origination, free from the extremes of eternalism and annihilationism.

original: p / hetum vāpavadataḥ phalaṃ vā kriyāṃ vā sad vā vastu nāśayata ityādi sucaritādikam /
analyzed: hetum vā apavadataḥ phalam vā kriyām vā sat vā vastu nāśayataḥ ityādi su carita ādikam
translated: By denying cause, effect, action, or an existent thing, etc., one destroys good conduct, etc.

analyzed: sugati durgatī
translated: Good and bad destinies,

analyzed: mātā ādi kriyām
translated: the action of mother, etc.,

analyzed: arhat ādikam ca yathākramam hetu ādikam
translated: and the Arhat, etc., are respectively cause, etc.

analyzed: kuśala mūla samuccheda karmikā akuśala mūla dṛḍha tā sat niśraya dāna karmikā ca iyam
translated: This [wrong view] functions to sever the roots of good and to give support to the firmness of the unwholesome roots.

analyzed: sā tu viśiṣṭā eva na sarvā
translated: But it is only the distinguished [wrong view], not all [wrong views].

analyzed: dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ katamaḥ iti
translated: What is clinging to rules and rituals?

analyzed: dṛṣṭi ādīn paratvena āmṛśati iti dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ
translated: Clinging to rules and rituals is clinging to views, etc. as supreme.

original: tām eva ca trividhāṃ dṛṣṭim iti satkāyadṛṣṭim antagrāhadṛṣṭiṃ mithyādṛṣṭiṃ ca /
analyzed: tām eva ca trividhām dṛṣṭim iti sat kāya dṛṣṭim anta grāha dṛṣṭim mithyādṛṣṭim ca
translated: And those very three views, namely the view of the transitory collection, the extreme views, and the false view,

analyzed: tad āśrayān ca skandhān iti
translated: and the aggregates that are their basis.

analyzed: ye draṣṭuḥ ātma bhāva saṃśabditāḥ
translated: Those that are called the body of the seer,

analyzed: yān āśritya dṛṣṭayaḥ pravartante
translated: depending on which the views arise.

analyzed: te tad āśrayā
translated: Those are their basis.

analyzed: agratas śreṣṭhatas viśiṣṭatas paramatas iti
translated: As supreme, as foremost, as distinguished, as highest.

analyzed: ete gṛ ādayaḥ śabdāḥ tulya arthāḥ api uttara uttara vyākhyāna tvena upāttāḥ
translated: These terms beginning with foremost have the same meaning, but are used as explanations in succession.

analyzed: ayam ca asat dṛṣi abhiniveśa sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ
translated: And this [mistaken belief in the supremacy of discipline and ritual] has the function of providing a basis for attachment to false views.

original: dṛṣṭilakṣaṇasyābhiniveśasya guṇarūpeṇa grahaṇāt tadaparityāgamukhena sarvadṛṣṭīnām ayaṃ sanniśraya ity uktaṃ bhavap / ti //
analyzed: dṛṣṭi lakṣaṇasya abhiniveśasya guṇa rūpeṇa grahaṇāt tad a parityāga mukhena sarva dṛṣṭīnām ayam san niśrayaḥ iti uktam bhavap
translated: Because it grasps the characteristics of views as having the form of virtues, it is said that this [mistaken belief in the supremacy of discipline and ritual] is the basis for all views by way of not abandoning them.

analyzed: śīlam vratam tad āśrayān ca skandhān iti
translated: [The verse says] discipline, ritual, and the aggregates that are their basis.

analyzed: dauḥśīlya viratiḥ śīlam
translated: Discipline is the avoidance of immorality.

original: veśavṛttakāyavākpravṛttirniyamo vratam /🔽yān āśritya skandhāñ chīlaṃ vrataṃ vā pravartate /
analyzed: veśa vṛtta kāya vāc pravṛttiḥ niyamaḥ vratam  yān āśritya śīlam vratam vā pravartate
translated: Ritual is the restriction of bodily and verbal conduct.

analyzed: te śīla vrata āśrayāḥ skandhāḥ
translated: The aggregates that are the basis for discipline or ritual are those aggregates upon which discipline or ritual depend.

original: kutsitāṃ dṛṣṭiṃ guṇato gṛhītvā tatpūrvakaṃ śīlaṃ vrataṃ vā paratvenāmṛśatīti śīlavrataparāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: kutsitām dṛṣṭim guṇataḥ gṛhītvā tad pūrvakam śīlam vratam vā paratvena āmṛśati iti śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ
translated: Mistaken belief in the supremacy of discipline and ritual is the grasping of a contemptible view as having virtues, and the grasping of the discipline or ritual that is based on that [view] as being supreme.

original: ata eva śīlavrataparāmarśād dṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ pūrva uktaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva śīla vrata parāmarśāt dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ pūrvaḥ uktaḥ
translated: For this very reason, mistaken belief in the supremacy of discipline and ritual is stated first, before mistaken belief in the supremacy of views.

original: śudhyate 'nena vā pāpācayanāt / śīlena vratena ceti śuddhiḥ /
analyzed: śudhyate nena vā pāpa ācayanāt śīlena vratena ca iti śuddhiḥ
translated: Purity is that by which one is purified, by discipline and ritual, because of the removal of evil.

analyzed: mucyate nena kleśa bandhāt iti muktiḥ
translated: Liberation is that by which one is liberated from the bondage of afflictions.

analyzed: niryāti anena saṃsārāt iti niryāṇam
translated: The meaning is: By this, one goes out of samsara, so it is a going out.

original: niryāṇam eva nairyāṇiko mokṣamārga ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: niryāṇam eva nairyāṇikaḥ mokṣa mārgaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The path of liberation is the going out itself.

analyzed: samanupaśyataḥ iti nirūpayataḥ
translated: By observing is meant: by investigating.

original: śīle vrate vā śuddhyādyākārair abhiniveśātmikā prajñā śīlavrataparāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: śīle vrate vā śuddhi ādi ākāraiḥ abhiniveśa ātmikā prajñā śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ
translated: The view that morality and ritual are supreme is the wisdom that consists in the attachment to the notion of purity, etc., in relation to morality and ritual.

analyzed: kliṣṭā tu viparīta ālambana tvāt
translated: But it is defiled because it has an inverted object.

analyzed: ayam ca śrama vaiphalya sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ
translated: And this [view] has the function of giving support to the futility of effort.

analyzed: vicikitsā katamā
translated: What is doubt?

analyzed: satya ādiṣu yā vimatiḥ iti
translated: It is indecision about the truths, etc.

analyzed: ādi śabdena karma phala ratnāni gṛhyante
translated: By the word etc. karma, its results, and the jewels are included.

original: dvidhā matir vimatiḥ syān na syād p / iti /
analyzed: dvidhā matiḥ vimatiḥ syāt na syāt iti
translated: Doubt is twofold: whether there is or is not, whether it is so or not so.

analyzed: prajñātaḥ ca iyam jāti antaram eva draṣṭavyā
translated: And this [doubt] should be seen as a separate category from wisdom.

original: sā kuśalapakṣāpravṛttisanniśrayadānakarmikā //🔽kleśānāṃ ca rāgādīnāṃ kati parikalpitā eva /
analyzed: sā kuśala pakṣa apravṛtti sanniśraya dāna karmikā  kleśānām ca rāga ādīnām kati parikalpitāḥ eva
translated: And it has the function of giving support to the non-engagement in the wholesome.

original: kati sahajāḥ parikalpitāś cety āha tisro dṛṣṭayaḥ parikalpitāḥ eveti /
analyzed: kati sahajāḥ parikalpitāḥ ca iti āha tisraḥ dṛṣṭayaḥ parikalpitāḥ eva iti
translated: And how many of the defilements such as attachment are only imagined, and how many are both innate and imagined? He says: The three views are only imagined.

original: tās tu pūrvā api santīty ata āha paścimā iti /
analyzed: tāḥ tu pūrvāḥ api santi iti atas āha paścimāḥ iti
translated: But they also exist previously, therefore he says: the latter [views].

original: tāḥ punar mithyādṛṣṭir dṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ śīlavrataparāmarśaś ca /
analyzed: tāḥ punar mithyā dṛṣṭiḥ dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ ca
translated: Moreover, they are wrong view, grasping at false views, and grasping at mere rules and rituals.

analyzed: na kevalam etāḥ eva parikalpitāḥ
translated: Moreover, they are not only imagined.

analyzed: kim tarhi vicikitsā ca parikalpitā
translated: What else? Doubt is also imagined.

analyzed: śeṣāḥ sahajāḥ parikalpitāḥ ca iti ubhayathā
translated: The remaining [afflictions] are both innate and imagined.

analyzed: ke punar śeṣāḥ
translated: What are the remaining [afflictions]?

analyzed: rāga pratigha māna avidyāḥ sat kāya dṛṣṭiḥ anta grāha dṛṣṭiḥ ca
translated: Attachment, anger, pride, ignorance, the view of the transitory collection, and the view grasping at extremes.

analyzed: uktāḥ kleśāḥ upakleśāḥ vaktavyāḥ
translated: The afflictions have been explained. The secondary afflictions should be mentioned.

analyzed: te ucyante
translated: They are said to be:

analyzed: vartamānam pratyutpannam
translated: The present is the present.

analyzed: nānāgatam atītam vā
translated: Not the future or the past.

original: apakāram āgamyety apakāraṃ gṛhītvety anena krodhasya viṣayaṃ nirūpayati /
analyzed: apakāram āgamya iti apakāram gṛhītvā iti anena krodhasya viṣayam nirūpayati
translated: Having taken offense means having grasped an offense. By this, he determines the object of anger.

original: krodho hy apakāravastuny eva vartamāna eva pravartate /
analyzed: krodhaḥ hi apakāra vastuni eva vartamānaḥ eva pravartate
translated: For anger arises only in relation to an offense, only in the present,

analyzed: na anyatra iti
translated: not elsewhere.

original: cetasa āghāta ity atrāpi vijñānasambandhitvaṃ svarūpaṃ ca nirūpitam /
analyzed: cetasaḥ āghātaḥ iti atra api vijñāna sambandhi tvam svarūpam ca nirūpitam
translated: Here too, in mental hostility, the connection with consciousness and its own nature are determined.

analyzed: ayam ca āghāta sva rūpa tvāt pratighāt na bhidyate
translated: And this [resentment] is not distinguished from anger, because it has the nature of hostility.

analyzed: kim tarhi pratigha aṃśikaḥ eva
translated: Then what is it?

analyzed: pratighasya āṃp viśeṣe prajñapta tvāt
translated: It is designated as a particular part of anger.

original: vartamānam apakāram adhikṛtya yaś cetasa āghātaḥ sattvāsattvaviṣayo daṇḍādānādisanniśrayadānakarmakaś ca sa krodha iti prajñapyate //
analyzed: vartamānam apakāram adhikṛtya yaḥ cetasaḥ āghātaḥ sattva asattva viṣayaḥ daṇḍa ādāna ādi sanniśraya dāna karmakaḥ ca sa krodhaḥ iti prajñapyate
translated: Anger is the mental state of hostility toward a present harm-doer, whether a sentient being or not, and its action is to give support to the giving of punishment, etc.

original: krodhād ūrdhvaṃ mamānenedam apakṛtam ity etasya vairātmakasyāśayasyānubandho 'nutsargaḥ /
analyzed: krodhāt ūrdhvam mama anena idam apakṛtam iti etasya vaira ātmakasya āśayasya anubandhaḥ n utsargaḥ
